lessonOverview.title: Unit 2 - Lesson 2
structures: A: What’s the weather like today?
A: What’s the weather like in Paris?

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six types of weather (sunny, cloudy, rainy, snowy, foggy, windy) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use weather flashcards. Say: “It’s sunny.” Students point to the correct card. Mix cards up and repeat as a speed game.
stretchStrategies: Students give a “Weather Report” for 2 different cities (real or imagined), saying both the weather and date. Volunteers present to the class like a TV forecast.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about the weather using “What’s the weather like today?” / “What’s the weather like in...?” and respond with “It’s...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Daily weather report: Ask a volunteer each day: “What’s the weather like today?” They respond using the correct structure from the board.
stretchStrategies: Students give a “Weather Report” for 2 different cities (real or imagined), saying both the weather and date. Volunteers present to the class like a TV forecast.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structures “What’s the weather like today? It’s ___.” and “What’s the weather like in ___? It’s ___.” to talk about weather.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Display images of cities (e.g., Hanoi, London). Ask: “What’s the weather like in Hanoi?” Students answer using “It’s ___.”
stretchStrategies: Students give a “Weather Report” for 2 different cities (real or imagined), saying both the weather and date. Volunteers present to the class like a TV forecast.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
